title: Doppler - wavefront diagram - car and 2 students

content.question: Two students, Student <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are standing with a car moving between them at a safe distance, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The car is moving toward Student <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and away from Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> while the driver sounds the car’s horn. A third student, Student <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, correctly claims that Student <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> must observe a higher pitch from the car’s horn than Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> because of the Doppler effect. To justify this claim, Student <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> starts by drawing the diagram shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The diagram represents wavefronts of the sound waves emitted by the car’s horn. Is the student’s diagram an accurate representation of the wavefronts? What is a valid justification for why the diagram is or is not accurate?

choices.label: Yes. The diagram indicates that the waves travel in all directions outward from the car.

Yes. The diagram indicates that the distance between wavefronts is greater on the side closest to Student <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> than the side closest to Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

No. The diagram indicates that the waves reaching Student <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> have a lower frequency than the waves reaching Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

No. The diagram indicates that the waves reaching Student <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> have a faster speed than the waves reaching Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

content.answer: No. The diagram indicates that the waves reaching Student <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> have a lower frequency than the waves reaching Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
